statement.tex: \text{Find the inverse of the one-to-one function}\\ \quad f(x) = \dfrac{2x-1}{x+5}
\\ \textbf{Bonus Question} \\ \text{What are the range and domain of }f(x) = \dfrac{2x-1}{x+5}?

reason.tex: f^{-1}(x)\text{ is just another function.} \\ \textbf{Do not confuse with }\dfrac{1}{f(x)} = f(x)^{-1}.\\ \text{If f(x) takes you from }x\to y\text{, then }\\ f^{-1}(x)\text{ takes you from }y\to x.\\ \text{Mathematically, }\\ \begin{align} \text{If }f(x) &= y \\ \text{then }f^{-1}(y) &= x \end{align} \\ \text{Which is why }(f^{-1}\circ f)(x) = f^{-1}(\, f(x)\,) = x.

\begin{align} f(x) &= y = \dfrac{2x-1}{x+5}\implies 5y + xy = 2x - 1\\ \implies x &= \dfrac{5y + 1}{2-y} \end{align} \\ \text{So far, pretty straight-forward.} \\ \textbf{But notice something. }\text{In the above equation, }\\ \text{'x' is the independent variable (what you know)}\\ \text{and 'y' is the dependent variable (what you find).}\\ \underline{\text{But what if you only knew values for 'y'?}} \\ \text{Then you would think of 'y' as 'x' because}\\ \text{that is the only thing you know.} \\ \text{And you would use }g(x) = \dfrac{5x + 1}{2-x}\text{ to find}\\ \text{the 'x' that was used in }f(x). \\ \text{Hence, with }f(x) = \dfrac{2x-1}{x+5}, f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{5x + 1}{2-x}

\text{In }f(x) = \dfrac{2x-1}{x+5},\, f(x)\underline{\text{ is not defined}}\\ \text{when }x = -5\,(\because x + 5 = 0).\text{Otherwise, x can}\\ \text{be anything }\implies\textbf{ domain } = \mathbb{R}-\lbrace -5\rbrace. \\ \text{And if you recall that }x = \dfrac{5y + 1}{2-y},\text{ then you'll}\\ \text{notice that there is}\underline{\text{ no valid 'x' for }y = 2}.\\ \text{Hence, }y=2\text{ cannot be in the range of }f(x). \\ \implies\textbf{ range } = \mathbb{R} -\lbrace 2\rbrace.
